title: The Place | Budapest, Part Four
text:
Adrienn Szabo/Thinkfilm
PREP SCHOOL
Though Budapest is often stand-in for other cities in the movies, there is no shortage of cultural output celebrating the city itself. Here, a few notable valentines, classic and contemporary, to Hungary’s capital.
Films “Kontroll” (2003), directed by Nimrod Antal, is a comedy thriller set in Budapest’s subway system. In Agnes Incze’s “I Love Budapest” (2001), a country girl comes to the big city in search of a better life; expect drugs, sex and subtitles. “Sunshine” (1999), by Istvan Szabo, is a historic melodrama that chronicles three generations of a Hungarian Jewish family. “Budapest Portrait: Memories of a City” (1986), a black-and-white silent short, captures the historic city’s moody side. “The Witness” (1969), Peter Bacso’s famous (and formerly banned) cult film, satirizes post-World War II Hungary’s Communist regime.
Books Despite its title, “Prague: A Novel” by Arthur Phillips (Random House, 2003) follows five young expats in Budapest. “Budapest Noir: A Novel” by Vilmos Kondor (Agave Konyvek, 2008) is a 1930s murder mystery. In her memoir “Castles Burning: A Child’s Life in War” (Simon & Schuster, 1998), Magda Denes tells of being a young Jewish girl in fascist Hungary. In “Under the Frog” by Tibor Fischer (Picador, 1992), two precocious boys escape Communist Hungary and join a traveling basketball team. “The Door” by Magda Szabo (East European Monographs, 1995) tells the charming tale of a bewildering relationship between an author and her housekeeper.
